Award.AbstractNarration:
Teachers and undergraduate students participate in an integrated materials-focused summer research and education program at the Cornell Center for Materials Research (CCMR), a NSF Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC). Twelve undergraduate students funded by this grant join additional students funded by the MRSEC program to participate annually in a variety of 10-week-long research projects covering a broad range of materials-related topics including the synthesis, simulation and testing of new materials such as atomic membranes, complex oxides, carbon nanotubes and quantum dots, as well as devices made from novel materials such as single molecule transistors, solar cells, vaccine delivery vehicles, and green nanocomposites. A stimulating cohort experience is created through weekly seminars, field trips, workshops on communication and research ethics, a graduate school panel discussion, and a research symposium.

In addition, five middle school and high school teachers are introduced annually to scientific research through team research projects and curriculum development. The teachers are introduced to the tools of materials research through hands-on projects and then design experiments to solve posed challenges They also gain a broader understanding of materials science through a variety of activities and create a materials-oriented curriculum project suitable for their classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates program provided many undergraduate students with an introduction to materials research and encouraged students to pursue a graduate degree in a materials-related field. During the 10-week program which was offered each summer from 2011-2014, each student worked alongside faculty, postdocs, and graduate students on a carefully selected research topic. The student also participated in group meetings to learn about research of the other members of the lab and to present the progress of their own research. The research program was augmented by a number of professional development activities.

An additional objective of the program was to give undergraduates a better understanding of the interdisciplinary nature of materials research and employment opportunities in the field. This objective was advanced through a number of activities, including a lunchtime seminar series, a field trip to a world-leading industrial materials research laboratory, and a lunchtime panel that addressed life as a graduate student and the graduate admissions process.

Intellectual Merit: An exceedingly wide variety of scientific and engineering research was accomplished under this program. The REU projects resulted in many publications in science and engineering journals.

Broader Impacts: This program inspired and educated an outstanding and diverse cadre of young men and women in materials research thereby insuring the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. During the last funding period, 76% of CCMR REU students were from underserved populations (i.e., females, underrepresented minorities, and from schools with limited research opportunities). A longitudinal survey found that the program was very successful in meeting its long-term program goals, as more than 75% of the student participants who finished their undergraduate studies went on to graduate school.   

The principal objective of the Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program was to increase student achievement in science by providing professional development activities for middle school and high school teachers of mathematics, science, and technology (MST). This program directly met the recommendations of a recent high-profile National Academies study which concluded that one of the most effective ways to improve K-12 science and mathematics education is by strengthening teacher skills, in part through training and education programs at summer institutes. Research experience programs that target teachers have been shown to produce quantifiable, cost-effective gains in student achievement. The RET program included two factors that have been shown to be particularly beneficial to teachers: curriculum development activities and the possibility of a multiple-summer experience.

Intellectual Merit: The RET program enabled teachers from schools across the nation to each spend six weeks participating in hands-on research projects, developing materials-related curricula for their classrooms, and furthering their own scientific training. During this time, the teachers solved curricular challenges and learned about new innovations and experimental techniques with faculty. All curricular materials developed through the program are archived on the CCMR website where they act as a resource for teachers across the nation.

Broader Impacts: This program impacted student interest and achievement in science by providing professional development for middle school and high school teachers. Of the participating teachers, 47% were from low SES schools, and 40% were from minority-serving schools.
